messages.message:
Hi team, I've been playing around with the new UI and have a few pieces of initial feedback:
1. I do like the Project - App - Deployment nav bar at the top. It makes switching between apps and projects much easier. It also helps visualize these concepts for users who often have a hard time understanding everything
2. I do miss the settings button at the top. It might just be because I'm used to it at this point, but the new arrow dropdown next to project name for accessing settings doesn't seem as intuitive to me.
3. I did notice that "Mark run as reviewed" button is gone in the new UI. I don't get any indication that the changes that I've made in the human review have been saved. The only option out of this page is to go back, and I see that this saves the changes values when I come back, but it feels wrong to me.
4. I know that we got rid of "Mark document as reviewed" and introduced the blue/gray dots to indicate whether a document has been clicked on. But for documents that failed validations, there's no way to get rid of the red x's. If I look at a document with failed validations, I expect to be able to get rid of them whether through confirming the flagged values or altering them. The red x's draw more attention than the gray dots on the left hand panel, so I never feel like I'm done reviewing these docs.
5. What's the reason for aligning "Workspaces" and "Hub" the way they are aligned? It's not central and the new alignment seems awkward.

Thanks for trying out the new nav & sharing this @david.lee. Copying some folks from the design team for visibility, cc @alagu @Siya @Natasha.

For review, did you access this from the Review tab or from an app runs table?
On point 5 it looks like there is more space there than specified in the design cc @tj.serkes

@david.lee any validation errors would still not go away if you had clicked mark doc as reviewed button. The validation failures go away if you have made the correct change that corrects the failure after revalidation (which happens automatically after making updates)

I will look into the Mark run as reviewed button though. It should ideally be there with the settings in the dropdown?

@Udit I think that logic about validation errors makes sense if we’re talking about custom functions that check for specific business logic (eg. Amount X is less than amount Y). But if a value is flagged for not meeting field confidence threshold, and the human reviewer inputs another value, that will never get rid of the validation failure. 

@jack.robbins any thoughts?

I agree, there has never been a way for reviewers to get rid of those validations. Marking a document as reviewed would also keep them there.

This would probably be another functionality that allows reviewers to dismiss validation errors (which could potentially just be a frontend side thing) cc @jack.robbins

@Udit I may have accidentally dropped that button from the nav. If you’re adding it, you can find the nav here!
`webserver/shared/src/js/webpacked/apps/src/aihub/features/NavBar/components/SecondaryNav/AppResultsNav.tsx`

Yeah - if we want to add a way to dismiss the validations or do it automatically, that would be a separate enhancement. We'd want to run that by a few customer human review teams to get better signal, but the request makes sense. I'll create an enhancement ticket for the backlog.

@jack.robbins Thanks! If we haven't heard that feedback from any customers in the past, then it might not be that important. My thinking here is that the way we pitch validations to companies today centers around catching errors made by AI and having a human verify it. Once a human verifies it by either confirming or denying its accuracy, then I feel like the validation rule has finished its job and should disappear? Or have its status changed the "Checked" or something along those lines. Again, it could just be me :sweat_smile:
